member.name: M:Infragistics.Collections.SparseArray.Compact
member.summary: Removes data structures allocated for empty slots in the sparse array.

remarks.para: Over time setting non-null slots to null can result in sparse array holding onto data structures that are not necessary since all the associated slots are null values. Calling this method will cause the sparse array to release those data structures.

member.param: Index of the item in the sparse array.
If false and the item is hidden, returns -1. Otherwise returns the visible index as if it were visible.
member.returns: Visible index.

remarks.para: This method is typically used when the item at a specific index hasn't been allocated yet and one needs to calculate its visible index.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Collections.SparseArray.GetItemAtScrollIndexHelper(System.Int32,Infragistics.Collections.ICreateItemCallback,System.Boolean,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns the item at the specified scroll index. This method returns null if the scroll index is out of bounds.
member.param: Visible index at which to get the item.
Optional call back to create the item at the specified scroll index if none exists at that scroll index.

If false then the method return the item in this sparse array that contains the specified scroll index. If true then it may traverse down the sparse array hierarchy to get the item at the specified scroll index from a sparse array that's at a lower level.
If traverseHierarchy is false then this will be set to the scroll index relative to the returned item.

member.summary: Sets the owner data on all the items contained in the tree. Typically you do not need to call this as the sprase array automatically manages the owner data as you add and remove items. This is useful if you deserialize the sparse array and need to make sure that the owner data are set properly on the contained items.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.CalendarHelper.GetWeekNumberForDate(System.DateTime,System.Nullable{System.Globalization.CalendarWeekRule},System.Nullable{System.DayOfWeek},System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns the week number for a particular date using the specified CalendarWeekRule and FirstDayOfWeek.
member.param: DateTime
Optional week rule to use for the calculation
Optional first day of week to use for the calculation
Out integer to receive the year for which the week number belongs.
member.returns: Integer denoting the week number that the date belongs to.

remarks.p: The System.Globalization.Calendar's GetWeekOfYear method simply returns the number of weeks into the year that the date falls on. It does not seem to use the weekrule specified in the arguments. e.g. If the first day of week is sunday and the weekrule is Jan 1, then 12/31/2000 (Sunday) should return 1. Instead it returns 54 and 1/1/2001 (Monday) returns 1.
This routine returns the correct week number for the specified date based on the CalendarWeekRule and FirstDayOfWeek.

Note, this may be a week for a year other than the year of the date. e.g. 12/31/2000, week tt of Jan 1, and week start of sunday will return 1 because this date falls into the first week of the year 2001.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.CalendarHelper.GetWeekNumberForDate(System.DateTime,System.Globalization.CalendarWeekRule,System.DayOfWeek,System.Globalization.Calendar,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns the week number for a particular date using the specified CalendarWeekRule and FirstDayOfWeek.
member.param: DateTime
WeekRule to use for the calculation
First day of week to use for the calculation
Calendar to use for the calculations
Out integer to receive the year for which the week number belongs.
member.returns: Integer denoting the week number that the date belongs to.

remarks.p: The System.Globalization.Calendar's GetWeekOfYear method simply returns the number of weeks into the year that the date falls on. It does not seem to use the weekrule specified in the arguments. e.g. If the first day of week is sunday and the weekrule is Jan 1, then 12/31/2000 (Sunday) should return 1. Instead it returns 54 and 1/1/2001 (Monday) returns 1.
This routine returns the correct week number for the specified date based on the CalendarWeekRule and FirstDayOfWeek.

Note, this may be a week for a year other than the year of the date. e.g. 12/31/2000, week tt of Jan 1, and week start of sunday will return 1 because this date falls into the first week of the year 2001.

member.name: T:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode
member.summary: Enumeration indicating the type of color blend operation to be performed.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.Normal
member.summary: Uses the source color.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.Multiply
member.summary: Multiplies the backdrop and source color channel values.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.Screen
member.summary: Multiplies the complement of the color channel values.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.Overlay
member.summary: Similar to HardLight except the source is used as the backdrop.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.Darken
member.summary: Uses the darker of the backdrop and source color channels.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.Lighten
member.summary: Uses the lighter of the backdrop and source color channels.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.ColorDodge
member.summary: Brightens the backdrop to reflect the source color.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.ColorBurn
member.summary: Darkens the backdrop to reflect the source color

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.HardLight
member.summary: Creates an effect similar to shining a harsh spotlight on the backdrop.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.SoftLight
member.summary: Creates an effect similar to shining a diffuse spotlight on the backdrop.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.Difference
member.summary: Subtracts the darker of the colors from the lighter.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.Exclusion
member.summary: Produces an effect similar to Difference but lower in contrast

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.LinearBurn
member.summary: Darkens the backdrop to reflect the surface color

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.LinearDodge
member.summary: Lightens the backdrop to reflect the surface color

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.Subtract
member.summary: Subtracts the surface color from the backdrop

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.Divide
member.summary: Divides the surface color from the backdrop

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.PinLight
member.summary: If the surface color is light the backdrop colors darker are replaced.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.LinearLight
member.summary: Performs a linear burn or dodge of the backdrop depending on the surface color.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.VividLight
member.summary: Performs a color burn or dodge of the backdrop depending on the surface color.

member.name: F:Infragistics.ColorBlendMode.HardMix
member.summary: Changes the channel to either the lightest or darkest value if the sum of the backdrop and surface channel is greater than 255.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.IGridBagConstraint
member.summary: Interface for providing constraints to the grid-bag layout manager.
member.remarks: IGridBagConstraint interface is used to provide constraints of an item to the . class implements this interface so typically there is no need for you to implement this interface as you can use the GridBagConstraint objects directly to provide item constraints to the grid-bag layout manager.

summary.p: Column and Row define where the layout item will be placed in the virtual grid of the grid-bag layout. Column specifies the location horizontally while specifies the location vertically. These locations are the coordinates of the cells in the virtual grid that the grid-bag layout represents.
The leftmost cell has Column of 0. The constant specifies that the item be placed just to the right of the item that was added to the layout manager just before this item was added.
The default value is . Column should be a non-negative value.
Specifies the number of cells this item will span horizontally. The constant specifies that this item be the last one in the row and thus occupy remaining space.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.IGridBagConstraint.ColumnWeight
member.summary: Indicates how the extra horizontal space will be distributed among items. Default value is 0.0. Higher values give higher priority. The weight of the column in the virtual grid the grid-bag layout represents is the maximum ColumnWeight of all the items in the row.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.IGridBagConstraint.HorizontalAlignment
member.summary: Horizontal alignment of the item within its logical cell.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.IGridBagConstraint.Margin
member.summary: Indicates the padding around the layout item.

summary.p: Column and Row define where the layout item will be placed in the virtual grid of the grid-bag layout. Column specifies the location horizontally while specifies the location vertically. These locations are the coordinates of the cells in the virtual grid that the grid-bag layout represents.
The topmost cell has Row of 0. The constant specifies that the item be placed just below the item that was added to the layout manager just before this item was added.
The default value is . Row should be a non-negative value.
Specifies the number of cells this item will span vertically. The constant specifies that this item be the last one in the column and thus occupy remaining space.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.IGridBagConstraint.RowWeight
member.summary: Indicates how the extra vertical space will be distributed among items. Default value is 0.0. Higher values give higher priority. The weight of the column in the virtual grid the grid-bag layout represents is the maximum RowWeight of all the items in the column.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.IGridBagConstraint.VerticalAlignment
member.summary: Horizontal alignment of the item within its logical row.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.GridBagConstraintConstants
member.summary: Defines constants used by grid-bag constraint object.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.GridBagConstraintConstants.Relative
member.summary: This constant can be assigned to Column and Row to indicate that the cell be positioned relative to the last cell.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.GridBagConstraintConstants.Remainder
member.summary: This constant can be assigned to ColumnSpan and RowSpan to indicate that the cell occupy the rest of the row or the column respectively.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.GridBagConstraint.HorizontalAlignment
member.summary: Horizontal alignment of the item within its logical cell.

summary.p: Column and Row define where the layout item will be placed in the virtual grid of the grid-bag layout. Column specifies the location horizontally while specifies the location vertically. These locations are the coordinates of the cells in the virtual grid that the grid-bag layout represents.
The leftmost cell has Column of 0. The constant Relative specifies that the item be placed just to the right of the item that was added to the layout manager just before this item was added.
The default value is Relative. Column should be a non-negative value.
Specifies the number of cells this item will span horizontally. The constant Remainder specifies that this item be the last one in the row and thus occupy remaining space.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.GridBagConstraint.ColumnWeight
member.summary: Indicates how the extra horizontal space will be distributed among items. Default value is 0.0. Higher values give higher priority. The weight of the column in the virtual grid the grid-bag layout represents is the maximum ColumnWeight of all the items in the row.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.GridBagConstraint.Margin
member.summary: Indicates the padding around the layout item.

summary.p: Column and Row define where the layout item will be placed in the virtual grid of the grid-bag layout. Column specifies the location horizontally while specifies the location vertically. These locations are the coordinates of the cells in the virtual grid that the grid-bag layout represents.
The topmost cell has Row of 0. The constant Relative specifies that the item be placed just below the item that was added to the layout manager just before this item was added.
The default value is Relative. Row should be a non-negative value.
Specifies the number of cells this item will span vertically. The constant Remainder specifies that this item be the last one in the column and thus occupy remaining space.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.GridBagConstraint.RowWeight
member.summary: Indicates how the extra vertical space will be distributed among items. Default value is 0.0. Higher values give higher priority. The weight of the column in the virtual grid the grid-bag layout represents is the maximum RowWeight of all the items in the column.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Layouts.Primitives.GridBagConstraint.VerticalAlignment
member.summary: Vertical alignment of the item within its logical cell.

member.summary: Calculates the row/column values for the specified items to fill the layout area.
member.param: Items to auto-layout.
Direction in which to layout items.
If true all items will be auto-fitted within the layout area.
Layout are size.
Minimum number of logical rows of items.
Minimum number of logical columns of items.
Maximum number of logical rows of items.
Maximum number of logical columns of items.

If specified non-null, then items will be laid in such a way that they will be not be allowed to go beyond the edge of the container in the constrained orientation (unless other constraints force otherwise). If null then items will not be constrained in either orientation.
member.returns: Calculated layout information in the form of a GridBagLayoutItemDimensionsCollection instance.

member.summary: Gets the resize range of an item.
member.param: Layout container. Used for getting the layout area rect, which is used when auto-fitting the layout in in an area that's different than the preferred size of the layout.
Not used by the layout manager directly. It gets passed along to methods on the layout container.
Item being resized.
This will be set to how much smaller the item can be resized left of its right edge.
This will be set to how much larger the item can be resized right of its right edge.
This will be set to how much smaller the item can be resized above its bottom edge.
This will be set to how much larger the item can be resized below its bottom edge.

member.summary: Gets the resize range of an item.
member.param: Layout container. Used for getting the layout area rect, which is used when auto-fitting the layout in in an area that's different than the preferred size of the layout.
Not used by the layout manager directly. It gets passed along to methods on the layout container.
Item being resized.
This will be set to how much smaller the item can be resized left of its right edge.
This will be set to how much larger the item can be resized right of its right edge.
This will be set to how much smaller the item can be resized above its bottom edge.
This will be set to how much larger the item can be resized below its bottom edge.

Specifies whether items will be autofitted horizontally within the layout container rect. Items will be resized in such a way that the width of the preferred size of the resultant layout will be equal container rect's width.

Specifies whether items will be autofitted vertically within the layout container rect. Items will be resized in such a way that the height of the preferred size of the resultant layout will be equal container rect's height.
A list of items whose size will be synchronized during the resize operation with the specified or null/empty list if there are no items to be synchronized with the resize item.

member.summary: Resizes the specified layout items to the specified preferred sizes.
member.param: Object used to determine the layout area rect, which is used when auto-fitting the layout in in an area that's different than the preferred size of the layout.
Not used by the layout manager directly. It gets passed along to methods on the layout container.
A dictionary of the items to be resized and the preferred sizes to which they would like to be sized.

Specifies whether items will be autofitted horizontally within the layout container rect. Items will be resized in such a way that the width of the preferred size of the resultant layout will be equal container rect's width.

Specifies whether items will be autofitted vertically within the layout container rect. Items will be resized in such a way that the height of the preferred size of the resultant layout will be equal container rect's height.
When an item is resized, items aligned with the resize item need to change their is-auto state to false. This parameter will be assigned a list of items whose is-auto state needs to change to false.
Same as newIsWidthAutoState except for heights.
member.returns: Returns the new preferred sizes of one or more items that will result in the preferred sizes of the specified layout items.

member.name: T:Infragistics.ListParser
member.summary: A helper class for parsing text that contains list of strings separated by predefined item separator character. The strings can be optionally enclosed in quote characters. It also has methods for constructing such a text from a list of strings. It manages escaping and unescaping of special characters.

member.name: M:Infragistics.ListParser.#ctor(System.Char,System.Char,System.Char,System.Char)
member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: Open quote character. Examples: ", ', [, ( etc...
Close quote character. Examples: ", ', ], ) etc...
Escape character. Examples: \
Character to separate multiple items. Examples: , ; | etc...

member.name: M:Infragistics.ListParser.#ctor(System.Char[],System.Char[],System.Char,System.Char)
member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: Allowed open quote characters. Examples: ", ', [, ( etc... First one will be chosen when calling ConstructList method.
Allowed close quote character. Examples: ", ', ], ) etc... First one will be chosen when calling ConstructList method.
Escape character. Examples: \
Character to separate multiple items. Examples: , ; | etc...

member.summary: Aggregates items in the specified collections.
member.returns: Returns the array of items.

member.name: M:Infragistics.ListParser.CreateDefault(System.Char)
member.summary: Creates a default list parser that uses '\'' and '"' quote characters, '\\' escape character and the specified separator character.

member.name: M:Infragistics.ListParser.EscapeString(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Escapes all the special charactes in the specified text. If withinQuotes is true then it only escapes the special characters that need to be escaped within quotes, namely the quote characters and the escape character.
member.param: Text that needs to be escaped.

Whether the text is going to be enclosed in double quotes. If true then only escapes characters that need to be escaped in double quotes. Note that this method doesn't actually enclose the string in quotes.
Specifies whether to escape leading and trailing white space characters so they are not 'lost' when unescaping and processing.
member.returns: Returns the escaped text.

member.name: M:Infragistics.ListParser.GetNextSeparator(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the next un-escaped character in the text starting from the specified start index. Note that characters before the startIndex are not taken into consideration at all and therefore if the previous character to start index is an escape character, it will not be treated as such.

member.name: M:Infragistics.ListParser.NormalizeEscapement(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This method has the same effect as calling UnEscapeString and then calling EscapeString on the specified text. This ensures that the text is minimally escaped.
member.param: The text that should be normalized.
Whether the text is going to be enclosed in double quotes. If true then only escapes characters that need to be escaped in double quotes.
member.returns: A string that has been unescaped and then escaped.

member.name: M:Infragistics.ListParser.UnEscapeString(System.String)
member.summary: Unescapes all the escaped charactes in the specified text.
member.param: The text whose escaped characters should be unescaped.
member.returns: A string with all escaped characters unescaped.

member.summary: A custom panel that positions each item in a separate cell within a grid of evenly sized cells.

remarks.p: The number of rows and columns of cells are based on the and properties respectively. The first item is positioned based on the and . Each subsequent item is positioned in the next column. member.name: T:Infragistics.WeakReferenceHelper`1
member.summary: Represents a list that store weak references to values. This list allows to store values while still allowing that the values can be reclaimed by garbage collection and avoid memory leaks.
member.typeparam: Type of the values.
member.remarks: If a value is added to the list and after that it is released by the garbage collector, it is removed from the list automatically when the it detects that the weak reference is dead.

member.summary: Initialize a new instance of the WeakReferenceHelper class.

member.summary: Adds a range of items to the list

member.summary: Performs the specified action on each item of the list.
member.param: Action that is invoked with the item as argument. If it returns true the for each continues with the next item, if it returns false the for each stops (like including a break in code).

remarks.p: This attached property can be used for any purpose but was initially added to be used as the target of a local style trigger that would ultimately be referenced by a style setter. member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings
member.summary: Contains settings that support controls which implement Carousel views (e.g., and )).

remarks.p: The and the each expose a ViewSettings property ( and ) of type CarouselViewSettings. By manipulating properties on the CarouselViewSettings object you can control how the arranges and applies effects to items.

A partial list of the properties that affect layout and parent effects include:
- Specifies the path along which items are arranged
- Specifies a Brush used to fill the path
- Specifies a Pen used to outline the path
- Specifies the size of items
- Specifies the maximum number of items that should be displayed at any one time
- Specifies whether the contents of each item should be scaled to fit within the size specified for each item
- Specifies one or more EffectStops (i.e., Offset+Value pairs) that describe how Opacity effects should be applied to each item based on its position in the XamCarouselPanel
- Specifies one or more EffectStops (i.e., Offset+Value pairs) that describe how Scaling effects should be applied to each item based on its position in the XamCarouselPanel
- Specifies one or more EffectStops (i.e., Offset+Value pairs) that describe how Skewing about the X-axis should be applied to each item based on its position in the XamCarouselPanel
- Specifies one or more EffectStops (i.e., Offset+Value pairs) that describe how Skewing about the Y-axis should be applied to each item based on its position in the XamCarouselPanel
- Specifies one or more EffectStops (i.e., Offset+Value pairs) that describe how ZOrder effects should be applied to each item based on its position in the XamCarouselPanel
Refer to the documentation contained within for a complete list of the properties supported by this class and the functionality enabled by each property.
Refer to the Carousel Architecture Overview topic in the Developer's Guide for an explanation of how Carousel presentation works.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.AutoScaleItemContentsToFit
member.summary: Returns/sets whether the should automatically scale the contents of each item to fit within the bounds of the Item. The default is False.

remarks.p: The bounds of the Item is determined by the property. Note that while you can indirectly affect the size of the items by using , scaling effects are applied to items at render time after the setting of this property has taken effect.

When the AutoScalItemContentsToFit property is set to false, scrollbars will be shown by default within the item if necessary (i.e., if the size of the contents is greater than the size of the item) to enable scrolling of the contents. For explicit control over whether scrollbars are displayed in this case, you can set the and properties.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.CarouselPanelNavigatorStyle
member.summary: Returns/sets the style for the .

remarks.p: The control provides a UI for scrolling items in a

Setting the Style is the most convenient way to control the placement of the in the . By creating a style that contains Setters for the HorizontalAlignment and/or VerticalAlignment properties along with the Margin property, and assigning it to this property, you can place the navigator in a location that works best for the you are using.
By default the navigator is placed in the lower right corner of the control.

The displays buttons that execute when clicked, in order to scroll items. If you want to provide your own UI for scrollig items, you can hide the by setting the property to hidden and then creating a UI that executes the same scrolling commands used by the navigator.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.HeightInInfiniteContainers
member.summary: Returns/sets a value that is used as the default for the height of the , when it is placed in a container with infinite height available. The default is 300.

remarks.p: Certain controls such as and make an infinite amount of height and width available to the controls they contain. If you place a control that implements a Carousel view (e.g., or ) inside one of these controls you may want to set this property to constrain the height of the control to a convenient value. If you don't set this property a default height of 300 will be used.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.IsListContinuous
member.summary: Returns true if the should wrap around to the beginning of the list and display the first list item after the last item is displayed. The default is False.

remarks.p: Note: When this property is set to true and the total number of items in the list is less than the number of , page scrolling is disabled and line scrolling does not wrap to the other end of the list.

The and objects which wrap each item in the list, expose 2 properties: and , which you can use in a replacement Template for those objects to highlight the first and last items in the list when IsListContinuous is set to true. This makes it easier for the end user to tell when they have scrolled back to the beginning of the list.
Note: The default styles for the and objects do not highlight the first and last items.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.IsNavigatorVisible
member.summary: Returns/sets whether the is visible. The default is True.

remarks.p: The provides a UI for navigating through the list of items in the Carousel. It displays buttons that execute when clicked to scroll items. If you want to provide your own UI for scrollig items, you can hide the CarouselPanelNavigator by setting this property to hidden and then creating a UI that executes the same scrolling commands used by the navigator.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemHorizontalScrollBarVisibility
member.summary: Returns/sets the visibility of the horizontal that is displayed within each item when the width of the Item's contents exceeds the Item's width as specified by the property. The default is .Auto.

remarks.p: Note that this property is ignored if is set to true.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemVerticalScrollBarVisibility
member.summary: Returns/sets the visibility of the vertical that is displayed within each item when the height of the Item's contents exceeds the Item's height as specified by the property. The default is .Auto.

remarks.p: Note that this property is ignored if is set to true.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemPath
member.summary: Returns/sets the derived element (i.e., , , , , , ) which defines the used to arrange items in the . The default is null. When this property is set to null, an elliptical path is provided by default.

remarks.p: Note: The defined by the derived element will be scaled to fit within the taking into account the settings of the , , and properties. These properties let you precisely determine how the path is aligned and scaled within the .

A convenient way to create a path to assign to this property is to use Microsoft Expression Blend. Blend provides a great designtime experience for creating and manipulating the geometry of derived elements.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemPathAutoPad
member.summary: Returns/sets whether padding should be automatically added within the to ensure that items arranged along the path do not extend beyond the bounds of the control. The default is True.

remarks.p: Note: If this property is set to true and padding is automatically added, the added padding is in addition to any padding specified in the property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemPathHorizontalAlignment
member.summary: Returns/sets the of the within the item path area. The default is .Center.

remarks.p: The item path area is an area within the that is defined by applying the to the bounds of the .

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemPathPadding
member.summary: Returns/sets the padding around the item path area, within which the is aligned and stretched. The default is 0.

remarks.p: The item path area is an area within the that is defined by applying the to the bounds of the .

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemPathStretch
member.summary: Returns/sets how the is stretched within the item path area. The default is .Fill

remarks.p: The item path area is an area within the that is defined by applying the to the bounds of the .

The enumeration values are interpreted as follows:
None - The item path preserves its original size.
Fill - The item path is resized to fill the destination dimensions. The aspect ratio is not preserved.
Uniform - The item path is resized to fit in the destination dimensions while it preserves its native aspect ratio.
UniformToFill - The item path is resized to fill the destination dimensions while it preserves its native aspect ratio. If the aspect ratio of the destination rectangle differs from the source, the item path is clipped to fit in the destination dimensions.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemPathPrefixPercent
member.summary: Returns/sets the size of the path prefix area expressed as a decimal percentage of the overall path size (the percentage must be in the range 0.0 to 0.4). The default is .15.

remarks.p: The prefix area is located at the beginning of the path and is the area within which items are transitioned into and out of view during scrolling. Items appear in the prefix area only while they are transitioning into or out of view. When they are 'at rest', items appear in the area between the prefix and suffix areas.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemPathSuffixPercent
member.summary: Returns/sets the size of the path suffix area expressed as a decimal percentage of the overall path size (the percentage must be in the range 0.0 to 0.4). The default is .15.

remarks.p: The suffix area is located at the end of the path and is the area within which items are transitioned into and out of view during scrolling. Items appear in the suffix area only while they are transitioning into or out of view. When they are 'at rest', items appear in the area between the prefix and suffix areas.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemPathRenderBrush
member.summary: Returns/sets the used to fill a parent representation of the behind the items being displayed. By default, no is set.

remarks.p: For most path geometries, specifiying an ItemPathRenderBrush results in a compelling highlighting of the path area. However, using an ItemPathRenderBrush with some geometries may produce unexpected parent results. This is a function of how the WPF framework fills geometries.
Note: You can also specify an to provide an outline for the filled area.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemPathRenderPen
member.summary: Returns/sets the used to draw the outline of the behind the items being displayed. By default, no is set.

remarks.p: For most path geometries, specifiying an ItemPathRenderPen results in a compelling highlighting of the path area. However, using an ItemPathRenderPen with some geometries may produce unexpected parent results. This is a function of how the WPF framework outlines geometries.
Note: You can also specify an to provide a fill for the path area.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemPathVerticalAlignment
member.summary: Returns/sets the of the within the item path area. The default is .Center.

remarks.p: The item path area is an area within the that is defined by applying the to the bounds of the .

members.member:
Returns/sets the size of the items in the Carousel. The default is 150x100 (WxH). .
Note: The size specified by this property is applied to all items in the Carousel - you cannot specify different sizes for each item. However you can affect the rendering size of individual items implicitly by applying scaling effects to the items using the , and properties.
Note: The property determines whether the contents of each item is scaled to fit within the bounds of the item as determined by this property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemsPerPage
member.summary: Determines the maximum number of items that should be displayed in the at one time. The default is 5.

remarks.p: If the total number of items in the list is less than , the will spread out those items evenly along the so they take up all the space between the prefix and suffix areas.

For example, if the number of items per page is set to 10 and the total number of items in the list is 20, then the 10 displayed items will be arranged along the between the prefix and suffix areas using even spacing. If the number of items in the list is less than , say 5, then those 5 items will still be evenly arranged along the between the prefix and suffix areas, but with increased spacing so the entire area is used. This prevents items from being 'bunched up' at the beginning of the path.
Note: up to 2x items will be displayed at any given time while the is in the process of scrolling.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ItemTransitionStyle
member.summary: Returns/sets a value that determines the effects applied to items as they transition through the prefix and suffix areas of the . The default is .AdjustOpacity.

remarks.p: The prefix and suffix areas of the item path are reserved for items that are transitioning into and out of view during scrolling. The setting of this property determines whether items in these areas have their size or opacity automatically adjusted from normal settings to zero as they exit the path.
Note: The effects specified by the setting of this property are applied in addition to the effects (if any) specified by the various EffectStops properties.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.OpacityEffectStops
member.summary: Returns a collection of objects that define the stops to be used when setting the opacity of items along the

remarks.p: Note: the property must be set to true for these s to be applied.
The way in which the opacity effect stops are applied to each item is determined by the item's location in the display area of the and the setting of the property.

For example, if you are using a circular path and you want to give the user the sense that the items at the top of the circle are further away, set the this property to EffectStopDirection.Vertical and add OpacityEffectStops that range from a value of .6 at an Offset of zero to a value of 1 at an Offset of 1. This will make the items 'in the distance' appear a bit more transparent. To further enhance the perspective effect you can also do a similar thing with ScalingEffectStops - make items in the foreground (i.e., bottom of the circle) bigger and items in the back (i.e., top of the circle) smaller.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.OpacityEffectStopDirection
member.summary: Returns/sets the direction used to evaluate s. The default is .UseItemPath.

remarks.p: The direction can be set to evaluate the effect stops based on an item's position along the or based on the item's vertical or horizontal position within the .

For example, if you are using a circular path and you want to give the user the sense that the items at the top of the circle are further away, set the this property to .Vertical and add that range from a value of .6 at an Offset of zero to a value of 1 at an Offset of 1. This will make the items 'in the distance' appear a bit more transparent. To further enhance the perspective effect you can also do a similar thing with - make items in the foreground (i.e., bottom of the circle) bigger and items in the back (i.e., top of the circle) smaller.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ReserveSpaceForReflections
member.summary: Returns/sets whether the should reserve space for item reflections. The default is true.

remarks.p: If true, each will be sized to twice the height specified by the property to make room for the reflection.

Note: It is the responsibility of the Template within the CarouselPanelItem style to actually show the reflections in the additional space provided by this property. The default style for the does just that.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.RotateItemsWithPathTangent
member.summary: Returns/sets whether the should rotate each item based on the item position's tangent to the path. The default is False.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ScalingEffectStops
member.summary: Returns a collection of objects that define the stops to be used when scaling items along the to simulate perspective.

remarks.p: Note: the property must be set to true for these s to be applied.
The way in which the scaling effect stops are applied to each item is determined by the item's location in the display area of the and the setting of the property.

For example, if you are using a circular path and you want to give the user the sense that the items at the top of the circle are further away, set the this property to .Vertical and add s that range from a value of .6 at an Offset of zero to a value of 1 at an Offset of 1. This will make the items 'in the distance' appear a bit smaller. To further enhance the perspective effect you can also do a similar thing with s - make items in the foreground (i.e., bottom of the circle) opaque and items in the back (i.e., top of the circle) a bit transparent.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.ScalingEffectStopDirection
member.summary: Returns/sets the direction used to evaluate s. The default is .UseItemPath.

remarks.p: The direction can be set to evaluate the effect stops based on an item's position along the or based on the item's vertical or horizontal position within the .

For example, if you are using a circular path and you want to give the user the sense that the items at the top of the circle are further away, set the this property to .Vertical and add s that range from a value of .6 at an Offset of zero to a value of 1 at an Offset of 1. This will make the items 'in the distance' appear a bit smaller. To further enhance the perspective effect you can also do a similar thing with s - make items in the foreground (i.e., bottom of the circle) opaque and items in the back (i.e., top of the circle) a bit transparent.

remarks.p: Note: When the list is Reset, the items are always animated.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.UseOpacity
member.summary: Returns/sets whether and should be honored and opacity effects applied to items in the Carousel. The default is False.

remarks.p: When this property is set to false, any s that may be defined are ignored.
Note: The property can be used to apply additional effects to items as they transition into and out of view through the prefix and suffix areas of the .

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.UseScaling
member.summary: Returns/sets whether and should be honored and scaling effects applied to items in the Carousel. The default is True.

remarks.p: When this property is set to false, any s that may be defined are ignored.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.UseSkewing
member.summary: Returns/sets whether , , and should be honored and skewing effects applied to items in the Carousel. The default is False.

remarks.p: When this property is set to false, any s or s that may be defined are ignored.
Note: The property can be used to apply additional effects to items as they transition into and out of view through the prefix and suffix areas of the .

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.CarouselViewSettings.UseZOrder
member.summary: Returns/sets whether should be honored and ZOrder effects applied to items in the Carousel. The default is False.

remarks.p: When this property is set to false, any s that may be defined are ignored, and items will be ordered in the Z-space based on their position in the list (items with a lower list position will appear underneath and items with a higher list position with appear on top).
Note: The property can be used to apply additional effects to items as they transition into and out of view through the prefix and suffix areas of the .

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.IFilterEvaluator
member.summary: Interface for providing custom logic for evaluating filter comparison operators. It also lets you provide custom logic for converting left-hand-side and right-hand-side values before the default built-in logic evaluates the comparison operator.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.IFilterEvaluator.Evaluate(Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonOperator,System.Object@,System.Object@,Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ConditionEvaluationContext)
member.summary: Called to evaluate the specified comparison operator. This method can also be used to convert the comparison values using custom logic and let the default built-in evaluation logic handle the actual comparison.
member.param: Comparison operator.

Value on the left hand side of the operator. You can set this by-ref parameter to its converted form and return null from the method to have the default built-in logic perform the evaluation of the operator using the converted value.
Value on the right hand side of the operator. Similarly to 'lhs' parameter, you can also set this by-ref parameter to its converted form.
Evaluation context. You can use the context's method to store any cached value for retrival in successive calls via the context's method.
member.returns: Returns true if the comparison of the specified values using specified operator evaluates to true. Returns false if the comparison fails. Returns null if you want to let the default built-in logic to handle evaluation.

remarks.para: This method lets you evaluate the comparison operator. You can choose to evaluate specific operators only and let the default logic handle the evaluation of other operators by returning null. Another use for this method is to provide custom conversion logic for converting the and before the default built-in implementation evaluates the comparison. To do that you would set the 'lhs' and 'rhs' ref parameters to their converted representations and return null from the method. The default built-in evaluation logic will use the converted values.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ClippedTextToolTipService.AncestorTypeForToolTipProperty
member.summary: Identifies the AncestorTypeForToolTip attached dependency property

remarks.p: The AncestorTypeForToolTipProperty is used to identify an ancestor on which the tooltip should be placed. This allows that ancestor to show a tooltip when the it contains has its text clipped but allow the mouse to be anywhere over the ancestor to have that tooltip be displayed. By default, this property is null and the tooltip will be set on the TextBlock itself.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.PathItemTransitionStyle
member.summary: Determines the effects applied to items as they transition through the prefix and suffix areas of a 's .

remarks.p: The prefix area is located at the beginning of the path and the suffix area is located at the end of the path. These are the areas within which items are transitioned into and out of view during scrolling. Items appear in the prefix or suffix area only while they are transitioning (scrolling) into or out of view. When they are 'at rest', items appear in the area between the prefix and suffix areas.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.PathItemTransitionStyle.AdjustOpacity
member.summary: The opacity of items are adjusted from transparent to Opaque as the items pass through the prefix and suffix areas of the 's

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.PathItemTransitionStyle.AdjustSize
member.summary: The size of items are adjusted from full size to zero as the items pass through the prefix and suffix areas of the 's

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.PathItemTransitionStyle.AdjustSizeAndOpacity
member.summary: Both the size and opacity of items are adjusted as the items pass through the prefix and suffix areas of the 's

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.PageOrientation
member.summary: Identifies the page orientation

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.PageOrientation.Portrait
member.summary: The page will be oriented such that its height will be greater than its width.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.PageOrientation.Landscape
member.summary: The page will be oriented such that its width will be greater than its height.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.PagePrintOrder
member.summary: Identifies the order pages in a report when the is set to 'Mosaic' and logical pages are split up onto multiple pages.

remarks.p: When a logical page within a report is too wide to fit and is set to 'Mosaic' then it will be will be split up into multiple page parts horizontally. This property determines the order that the page parts are placed in the report.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.PagePrintOrder.Horizontal
member.summary: Each logical page will print all of its multiple page parts, left to right, before the next logical page is printed.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.PagePrintOrder.Vertical
member.summary: Every logical page will print its 'part 1' first. This will then be follwed by every logical page's 'part 2' etc.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.HorizontalPaginationMode
member.summary: Determines how to print a logical page when it it too wide to fit on a single page.

remarks.p: Note: if 'Scale' is specified then the aspect ratio will be maintained, i.e. the scale factor for the width and height will be the same.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.HorizontalPaginationMode.Scale
member.summary: When the logical width of the page too wide to fit on a single page then scale the page down so it does fit while maintaining its aspect ratio. In other words, the sale factor for the width and height will be the same.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.HorizontalPaginationMode.Mosaic
member.summary: When the logical width of the page too wide to fit on a single page then split it up onto multiple separate pages based on the setting.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.RepeatType
member.summary: Determines how logical headers within the page content area will be treated within a report section.

remarks.para: Note: In the case of a XamDataGrid this setting determines when field headers are displayed.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.RepeatType.FirstOccurrence
member.summary: Logical content headers appear only on the page where they occur for the first time.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.RepeatType.PageBreak
member.summary: Logical content headers appear at the top of the each new page.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Reporting.RepeatType.LevelBreak
member.summary: Logical content headers appear only when they are required when the context requires it, e.g. when record type changes.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonCondition
member.summary: Condition that compares two values using the operator specified by the property.

remarks.para: ComparisonCondition is an ICondition implementation that compares two values using the operator specified by the property. The value on the right hand side of the operator is specified by the property. The value being matched is the left hand side value, which is specified via the call to method.

Multiple conditions can be grouped using the class, which itself implements interface, allowing you to create an arbitrarily nested conditions. ConditionGroup's property is used to specify the boolean operator that will be used for combining multiple conditions in that particular condition group.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ICondition
member.summary: Provides common interface for testing a value to see if it matches a condition.

remarks.para: ICondition is an interface that various condition classes implement. It provides standard interface to check if a value matches a condition. Classes that implement this interface include , and .
Also see which is used along with to specify common useful conditions. Various SpecialOperandBase implementations are provided by the class via static properties (like , etc...).

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ICondition.IsMatch(System.Object,Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ConditionEvaluationContext)
member.summary: Returns true if the specified value matches the condition. False otherwise.
member.param: Value to test.
Context information on where the value came from.
member.returns: True if the value passes the condition, false otherwise.

member.summary: Constructor. Initializes a new instance of .

Compare value. This is the right hand side value of the comparison operator.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonCondition.#ctor(Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonOperator,System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor. Initializes a new instance of .
member.param: Comparison operator.
Compare value. This is the right hand side value of the comparison operator.
The text to return from the ToString() method.

remarks.para: Note: if DisplayText is supplied then the user will see the 'Equals' operator in a filter cell when this ComparisonCondition is selected. Also, if the operator is subsequently changed then the condition will be cleared. The reason for this behavior is that the display text may include context that is related to its own operator. Therefore, any additional operator displayed to the user (other than 'Equals') may be incorrect. For eaxmple, if the ComparisonCondition Operator was 'NotEquals', the Value was '0' and the DisplayText was 'None Zero'.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonCondition.Create(Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonOperator,System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Exception@)
member.summary: Creates a new ComparisonCondition instance based on the specified parameters.
member.param: Comparison operator
Comparison operand

Whether to validate if the operand is valid for the specified comparison operator. If true and the operand is invalid, then null will be returned and error will be set to the error message. If false, a new ComparisonCondition will be returned with the specified operator and operand, even if the operand is invalid.
If the value is invalid, this will be set to an error instance that provides information about why the condition could not be created.
member.returns: New ComparisonCondition instance.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonCondition.GetCompatibleComparisonOperators(System.Type,Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonOperator@)
member.summary: Gets comparison operators that are compatible with values of specified data type.
member.param: Operators compatible with values of this data type are returned.
This will be set to an operator that is most suitable as the default operator in an operator selection UI part of filtering UI.
member.returns: Operators compatible with values of specified data type.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonCondition.GetCompatibleComparisonOperators(System.Type,Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonOperator@,Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonOperator[]@)
member.summary: Gets comparison operators that are compatible with values of specified data type.
member.param: Operators compatible with values of this data type are returned.
This will be set to an operator that is most suitable as the default operator in an operator selection UI part of filtering UI.

This will be set to a list of default operators that are compatible with the specified data type in priority order where more preferred is before less preferred. This is used when filter drop-down items is explicitly specified and doesn't include the default operator. For example, if FilterDropDownItems in data presenter is set to a value that doesn't include 'StartsWith', which is the defaultUIOperator for string fields, then we have to select one of the operators from the explicitly specified FilterDropDownItems list, selecting what makes the most sense. That's where the priority comes into play.
member.returns: Operators compatible with values of specified data type.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonCondition.GetCompatibleComparisonOperator(System.Type,Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonOperatorFlags)
member.summary: Gets preferred comparison operator out of availableOperators for the specified data type. If none of the preferred operators are in the availableOperators flags, then it will return the operator associated with the first set bit in the availableOperators. If availableOperators parameter is empty (0), then it will return the default operator deemed the most appropriate for the specified data type.
member.param: Data type
Available operators
member.returns: Preferred comparison operator for the specified data type

member.summary: Gets or sets the text to use in the UI for the condition.

remarks.para: Note: if DisplayText is supplied then the user will see the 'Equals' operator in a filter cell when this ComparisonCondition is selected. member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonCondition.Operator
member.summary: Gets or sets the comparison operator.

remarks.para: Operator property specifies the operator that will be used when evaluating the condition to match a value. The property specifies the value on the right hand side of the operator. The left hand side value is the value that's being tested to see if it matches the condition (passed into the method).

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ComparisonCondition.Value
member.summary: Returns the comparison value. This is the value on the right hand side of the comparison operator.

remarks.para: Value property specifies the the value on the right hand side of the operator. The property specifies the operator that will be used when evaluating the condition to match a value. The left hand side value is the value that's being tested to see if it matches the condition (passed into the method).
Value can also be set to an instance of derived class. There are several built-in special operands exposed by the class as static properties. See for more information.

member.summary: Class used for grouping multiple conditions.

remarks.para: ConditionGroup class is used for grouping multiple conditions. ConditionGroup itself implements interface and therefore you can create arbitrarily nested groups of conditions.
Conditions contained in the condition group are combined using the logical operator specified by the property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ConditionEvaluationContext.AllValues
member.summary: Returns the set of values a member of which is currently being evaluated. This is used to evaluate conditions that require information regarding the associated set of values, for example a condition that matches values that are 'above average' require the average attribute of the set of values associated with the current value being evaluated. Such a condition would calculate the average of 'AllValues' and compare the value being evaluated with that average.

remarks.para: AllValues property returns the set of values a member of which is currently being evaluated. This is used to evaluate conditions that require information regarding the associated set of values, for example a condition that matches values that are 'above average' require the average attribute of the set of values associated with the current value being evaluated. Such a condition would calculate the average of 'AllValues' and compare the value being evaluated with that average.

For example, in XamDataGrid when 'AboveAverage' filter condition is selected on a field, AllValues will be all field values of the record collection associated with the current field value that's being evaluated. Note that once you calculate the particular attribute of the set of values (in our example the average), you can cache the value using the method which you can retrieve using for reuse in successive evalulation of other values in the set. GetUserData will return null initially and once you cache it using the , it will continue returning that value for evaluation of all other values in the set. When values in the set changes, the context owner (for example the data presenter) will make sure to clear the cache.

Note that accessing AllValues will cause the re-evaluation of filters on all items even if data of one item changes. For example, in XamDataGrid, with 'AboveAverage' as the condition, when a cell value in a record changes, the 'average' of all values is changed and therefore all records have to be re-evaluated to make sure that they are still above the new average.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ConditionEvaluationContext.CurrentValue
member.summary: Returns further information regarding the value thats being evaluated currently.

member.summary: Returns any custom comparer for comparing values when evaluating filter conditions.

remarks.para: Comparer property returns any custom comparer that may have been specified, for example the data presenter's FieldSettings' FilterValueComparer property.
Default implementation returns null.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ConditionEvaluationContext.IgnoreCase
member.summary: Indicates whether string comparisons should be done case-insensitive or case-sensitive.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.ConditionEvaluationContext.PreferredComparisonDataType
member.summary: Indicates the data type that should be used to coerce values before performing quantitative comparisons.

remarks.para: PreferredComparisonDataType indicates the data type that should be used to coerce values before performing comparison. This is only applicable to quantitative comparison operators, like GreaterThan, LessThan etc and does not apply to string comparison operators like StartsWith, Contains etc This property will typically return the underlying data type of the field. For example, in data presenter this will be the fields EditAsTypeResolved which defaults to the Field's DataType.

member.summary: Used for caching any value.

remarks.para: UserCache is used for caching any value that can be used during evaluations of further values in the set. See for more information.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.SpecialFilterOperandBase
member.summary: Abstract base class for special filter operands.

remarks.para:
SpecialFilterOperandBase is the abstract base class for various special filter operands. Built-in special operands are exposed by the class as static properties, like , ,
etc... which can be used to specify the operand value on .

You can define a custom operand by deriving a class from this class and registering an instance with the ' method. This will automatically integrate your custom operand with controls/features that are aware of the special filter operands (like the data presenter's record filtering functionality). Also you can replace built-in special operands with your own custom operand by unregistering the built-in operand and registering your instance of the operand with the same name.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.SpecialFilterOperandBase.UsesAllValues
member.summary: Indicates whether this operand uses contexts AllValues property to evaluate the condition. In effect, it indicates whether condition evaluation of a value depends on other values in the set of values being evaluated.

remarks.para: UsesAllValues property indicates whether this operand uses contexts property to evaluate the condition. In effect, it indicates whether condition evaluation of a value depends on other values in the set of values being evaluated. For example, in data presenter, AboveAverage condition would be a condition where to determine whether a value is above the average, all values of the field need to be taken into account. This also indicates to the data presenter that when a fields value is changed in any record, all records need to reevaluate the condition in order to reflect correct results based on the new average of the field values.

Note that for such operands that use to calculate an attribute of the set of values (for example, average), you can cache the calculated value using the property. This property will return the value that it's set to for evaluation of the rest of the values in the set of values (for example, all field values in a record collection in data presenter). This way you can avoid re-calculating the same value again. Note that the caller (data presenter) will clear out the cached value once all the values are evaluated. Also note that when the data changes, the caller (data presenter) will clear the user cache and therefore you don't need to keep track of data changes.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.SpecialFilterOperandFactory.TopValuesOperand
member.summary: Special operand for filtering values that are among top specified number of values or top specified percentage of values.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.SpecialFilterOperandFactory.TopValuesOperand.#ctor(System.String,System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructor. Initializes a new instance of .
member.param: Name of the operand.
Specifies either the top absolute number of values or top percentage of values depending on 'percentage' parameter.
If true then values that are among specified top percentage are filtered. Otherwise the 'topNumber' parameter specifies the absoulte number of values.
If true then top-most (largest) values will be returned, otherwise bottom-most (smallest) values will be returned.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.SpecialFilterOperands
member.summary: Maintains a registry of special filter operands and also exposes built-in special filter operands as static properties.

remarks.para: SpecialFilterOperands maintains a registry of special operands. It exposes built-in special operands via static properties, like , , etc...

You can use SpecialFilterOperands class to and custom as well as built-in special filter operands. You can replace the logic for a built-in operand by un-registering it and then registering your own custom special operand instance with the same name. Controls and features aware of special filter operands (like the record filtering functionality of the data presenter) will automatically integrate the registered special operands with their UI.

member.summary: Constructor. Initializes a new instance of .

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.SpecialFilterOperands.GetSerializationValue(Infragistics.Windows.Controls.SpecialFilterOperandBase)
member.summary: If the specified operand is not one of our operands that we know about serializing, then we will create a wrapper that will serialize out the name of the operand. This will anyone who registers custom operands don't have to also write logic to serialize them out.
member.param: Source operand for which to create wrapper.
member.returns: If source is one of our operands, then returns null. Otherwise creates a wrapper object.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.SpecialFilterOperands.RegisterSerializationInfos(Infragistics.Windows.Internal.ObjectSerializerBase)
member.summary: Registers serialization information for special operands defined in this factory.

member.summary: Creates an operand used to compares dates to a range of dates based on a given relative date and the granularity to which the dates should be compared (e.g. compare the year).
member.param: A date that will be used to calculate the range for the comparison.
Defines how much of the date should be compared.
member.returns: Returns an operand that can be used to compare for a specific range of dates.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.UniformGridEx
member.summary: A custom panel that positions each item in a separate cell within a grid of evenly sized cells.

remarks.p: The number of rows and columns of cells are based on the and properties respectively. The first item is positioned based on the and . Each subsequent item is positioned in the next column. When there are no more columns within the row, the next item will be positioned in the first cell of the next row.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.PopupHelper.GetHandleMouseDownOnClose(System.Windows.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Returns a boolean indicating if the PreviewMouseDown of the Popup should be marked as handled when the Popup is closed.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Controls.PopupHelper.SetHandleMouseDownOnClose(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns a boolean indicating if the PreviewMouseDown of the Popup should be marked as handled when the Popup is closed.

remarks.p: The current implementation of a is to close itself during the PreviewMouseDown tunnel event and release capture. However, it does not mark the PreviewMouseDown as handled and so the element on which you clicked will still receive a MouseDown event. In certain cases, it is preferrable to have the mouse down that caused the click to be intercepted and not affect the element on which it was clicked until the subsequent mouse click. Setting this property to true will ensure that if the Popup's PreviewMouseDown is invoked and not handled even though the Popup was closed that the PreviewMouseDown is handled and therefore the element on which the mouse was clicked will not receive the MouseDown.
Note: This property will not affect a popup type implementation whereby the popup was closed during the PreviewMouseDownOutsideCapturedElement.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.AllowTileDragging.No
member.summary: Tiles can not be dragged from one location to another

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.AllowTileDragging.Swap
member.summary: A tile can be dragged to a new location. The Tile is repositioned when the drop occurs at which time its swaps its location with the Tile being dropped upon.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.AllowTileDragging.Slide
member.summary: A tile can be dragged to a new location. During the drag operation other tiles are dynamically animated over to make room for the Tile being dragged.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.ExplicitLayoutTileSizeBehavior
member.summary: Determines whether tile heights are synchronized across columns and whether tile widths are synchronized across rows when is set to 'UseExplicitRowColumnOnTile'

remarks.para: If there are ColumnsSpan values specified > 1 on one or more tiles then all tiles in intersecting columns will behave as if this setting was 'SynchronizeTileWidthsAndHeights' with respect to all other tiles in those intersecting columns.

Likewise, if there are RowSpan values specified > 1 on one or more tiles then all tiles in intersecting rows will behave as if this setting was 'SynchronizeTileWidthsAndHeights' with respect to all other tiles in those intersecting rows.

Note: regardless of the value of this setting if the overall size is constrained (e.g. if the HorizontalTileAreaAlignment and/or VerticalTileAreaAlignment is set to 'Stretch') then resizing a tile's width may indirectly affect the width of all tiles and resizing its height may indirectly affect the height of all tiles respectively.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.ExplicitLayoutTileSizeBehavior.SynchronizeTileWidthsAndHeights
member.summary: Tile heights and widths are synchronized across all row and columns in the layout. For example, resizing a tile's height in one column will affect the height of tiles in all columns that intersect with the resized tile's row. Likewise, resizing its width will affect the width of tiles in all rows that intersect with the resized tile's column.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.ExplicitLayoutTileSizeBehavior.SynchronizeTileWidthsAcrossRows
member.summary: Tile widths are synchronized across all rows in the layout. For example, resizing a tile's width in one row will affect the width of tiles in all rows that intersect with the resized tile's column. However, resizing its height will affect only that tile unless column spans > 1 are specified that intersect with the tile's column.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.ExplicitLayoutTileSizeBehavior.SynchronizeTileHeightsAcrossColumns
member.summary: Tile heights are synchronized across all columns in the layout. For example, resizing a tile's height in one column will affect the height of tiles in all columns that intersect with the resized tile's row. However, resizing its width will affect only that tile unless row spans > 1 are specified that intersect with the tile's row.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.MaximizedTileLayoutOrder
member.summary: Determines how the maximized tiles will be arranged.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.MaximizedTileLayoutOrder.VerticalWithLastTileFill
member.summary: Arrange maximized tiles one after another from top to bottom to fill all available space then move to the next column in a snaking fashion. If the resulting number of rows times columns doesn't exactly match the number of maximized tiles then the last tile will span any remaining rows in order to fill up all the avaialble space in the maximized area.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.MaximizedTileLayoutOrder.Vertical
member.summary: Arrange maximized tiles one after another from top to bottom to fill all available space then move to the next column in a snaking fashion.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.MaximizedTileLayoutOrder.HorizontalWithLastTileFill
member.summary: Arrange maximized tiles one after another from left to right to fill all available columns then move to the next row below in a snaking fashion. If the resulting number of rows times columns doesn't exactly match the number of maximized tiles then the last tile will span any remaining columns in order to fill up all the avaialble space in the maximized area.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.MaximizedTileLayoutOrder.Horizontal
member.summary: Arrange maximized tiles one after another from left to right to fill all available columns then move to the next row below in a snaking fashion.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.MaximizedTileLayoutOrder.SingleColumn
member.summary: Arrange maximized maxmized tiles vertically, one on top of the other.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.MaximizedTileLayoutOrder.SingleRow
member.summary: Arrange maximized maxmized tiles horizontally, left to right.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.MaximizedTileLocation
member.summary: Determines where the maximized tile area will be relative to the minimized tile area

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.MaximizedTileLocation.Left
member.summary: Maximized tiles are arranged on the left therefore minimized tiles are on the right.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.MaximizedTileLocation.Right
member.summary: Maximized tiles are arranged on the right therefore minimized tiles are on the left.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.MaximizedTileLocation.Top
member.summary: Maximized tiles are arranged on the top therefore minimized tiles are on the bottom.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.MaximizedTileLocation.Bottom
member.summary: Maximized tiles are arranged on the bottom therefore minimized tiles are on the top.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.TileLayoutOrder
member.summary: Determines how the tiles will be laid out in normal mode

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.TileLayoutOrder.Vertical
member.summary: Position tiles one after another from top to bottom to fill all available space vertically then move to the next column in a snaking fashion to form uniform rows and columns.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.TileLayoutOrder.VerticalVariable
member.summary: Position tiles one after another from top to bottom to fill all available space vertically then move to the next column in a snaking fashion supporting variable height tiles so that each column can have a different number of tiles.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.TileLayoutOrder.Horizontal
member.summary: Position tiles one after another from left to right to fill all available columns then move to the next row in a snaking fashion to form uniform rows and columns.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.TileLayoutOrder.HorizontalVariable
member.summary: Position tiles one after another from left to right to fill all available space horizontally then move to the next row in a snaking fashion supporting variable width tiles so that each row can have a different number of tiles.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.TileLayoutOrder.UseExplicitRowColumnOnTile
member.summary: Position tiles based on their explicit Row, RowSpan, Column, and ColumnSpan settings.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.TileState
member.summary: Represents the state of an indiviual tile

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.TileState.Normal
member.summary: All tiles will return 'Normal' as long as no tile is in a 'Maximized' state. Conversely if any Tile is 'Maximized' then no Tile with return 'Normal'.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.TileState.Maximized
member.summary: If any tile is in a 'Maximized' state then all other tiles can only be 'Maximized', 'Minimized' or 'MinimizedExpanded'.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.TileState.Minimized
member.summary: 'Minimized' is only returned if there is at least one tile in a 'Maximized' state. A Tile in the 'Minimized' state will usually just display its Header not its Content.

member.name: F:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.TileState.MinimizedExpanded
member.summary: 'MinimizedExpanded' is only returned if there is at least one tile in a 'Maximized' state. A Tile in the 'MinimizedExpanded' state will usually display its Header and its Content but the Tile will be grouped with all other minimized Tiles, both collapsed and expanded.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Virtualization.RecyclingItemsPanel.BeginGeneration(Infragistics.Windows.Selection.ScrollDirection)
member.summary: Called at the beginning of the generation process.

remarks.para: This method is usually called at the beginnning of a derived class's MeasureOverride logic. This is normally followed by one or more / loops to generate all 'active' containers. Finally, the method is called at the end of the measure logic.

member.param: Relative to the last generation to let the generator optimize the recycling logic.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Virtualization.RecyclingItemsPanel.BeginGeneration(Infragistics.Windows.Selection.ScrollDirection,System.Collections.IEnumerable)
member.summary: Called at the beginning of the generation process.

member.param: Relative to the last generation to let the generator optimize the recycling logic.
An optional list of items are are expected to be generated. This is used to optimize eleme nt recycling.

member.summary: Gets the actual extent of the minimized area
member.returns: An value that represents the actual width of the minimized area in maximized mode when MaximizedTileLocation is 'Left' or 'Right'. When MaximizedTileLocation is 'Top' or 'Bottom', it represents the actual height.

remarks.para: Note: if not in maximizd mode then this method returns 0.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Windows.Tiles.TilesPanelBase.GetItemsInView
member.summary: Returns an array if objects representing all of the items that will be arranged in view.

remarks.para: Note: this array represents the items that will be in view after pending animations have been completed. Also, in normal mode with a of 'UseExplicitRowColumnOnTile' all items will be returned from this list, not just those in view, since in this mode all items are measured and arranged.

member.returns: An array of ItemInfoBase objects

member.returns: A rect of the tile area that includes maximized tiles
